title.rendered: Planning a New Small Business? Follow These Easy Steps

content.rendered:
Planning a small business is an excellent way to become your own boss and move away from working for someone else. But you need to be sure you do things right in order to see the highest level of success. Here are some steps to take, so you can get your business started in a way that’s healthy and productive.

Write a Business Plan, and Keep It to One Page

Your small business needs a business plan, but you don’t want to have such a large plan that you get confused about what matters most. Keeping your business plan to one page, at least in the beginning stages of your company’s creation, can make it easier for you to have a strong focus on the kinds of things that are really important.

Pick a Budget and Stick With It

You can’t spend unlimited funds on your new business venture unless you have unlimited resources. Since most people don’t have that option, they need a budget. Set yours, make it realistic, and stick with it. There may be some small adjustments that have to be made, but overall you want to be clear on what you’re going to spend, right from the beginning.

You Need to Pick a Legal Status for Your Business

Are you going to be a sole proprietorship? An LLC? Something else? Determine a business’ legal status is important. Yes, you can change it later, but it’s easier if you start out with the status that you’re going to be keeping. That way you can avoid legal hassle later, and keep your business streamlined and moving forward. The less you have to go back and change things, the more easily you can focus on the daily operation of your business.

Make Sure You Understand the Money

Most businesses don’t make money in their first year, and yours could very well be the same way. Do you have money set aside to keep your business running during that time? What will you do if your business doesn’t succeed? You need a Plan B, but you also need to know how much money you protect will come in and go out. As you build more clients that could change, but right at the beginning you’ll likely have limited cash coming into your business and will still need to cover your expenses properly.

Get a Domain Name and Website

Before you name your business, check to see if that domain name is available. If it’s not, you may want to consider choosing a different name for your company. That’s because you’ll want to have a domain that makes sense for your business, and you’ll also want to build a website under that domain name. If it’s already taken, especially if it’s by a competitor or by a company you don’t want associated with your business, you might end up having trouble that you’d prefer to avoid. Taking the time to check first can save a lot of trouble later.

Test Out Sales Before You Jump in Fully

With some test sales you can get a better idea of whether customers are going to be receptive to the product or service you have, and the price you’re charging for it. If people aren’t receptive you can make changes while still in the test phase, to see if that improves your odds. After you’re done fine-tuning, you’ll have a much better idea of whether to launch your small business venture.

If you’re planning for the creation of a small business, you’ll want to make sure you have a credit card payment processor behind you. That way your customers can get what they need from visiting your company, and will be able to efficiently buy what you have to offer.
